heading.title: PART 2 THE DISTRICT COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 8–18L]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: PART 2 THE DISTRICT COURT OF NEW SOUTH WALES [ss 8–18L]
[DCA s 12] s 12 Composition of the Court

p.text: The Court shall be composed of a Chief Judge and such other Judges as the Governor may from time to time appoint.

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 13] s 13 Appointment and qualification of Judges

p.text: The Governor may, by commission under the public seal of the State, appoint any qualified person as a Judge.
[subs (1) subst Act 85 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 2]
In this section:
means any of the following persons:
a person who is an Australian lawyer of at least 7 years’ standing,
a person who holds or has held a judicial office of this State or of the Commonwealth, another State or a Territory,
without limiting paragraph (a) or (b), the Chief Magistrate of the Local Court.
[repealed]

[subs (2) insrt Act 85 of 2001 s 1 and Sch 2 ; am Act 7 of 2002 s 3 and Sch 3, effective 17 April 2002; Act 120 of 2006 s 3 and Sch 3[3.8] , effective 4 December 2006 ; Act 63 of 2010 Sch 1.9[1] , effective 28 June 2010]
The following provisions apply to and in respect of the Chief Magistrate of the Local Court if he or she also holds office as a Judge:

service by the Chief Magistrate in the office of the Chief Magistrate (during any period for which he or she also holds office as a Judge) is, for the purposes of this Act (including section 15) and the Judges’ Pensions Act 1953, taken to be service in the office of a Judge,
the Chief Magistrate may not hear or determine an appeal in his or her capacity as a Judge from any decision made by the Chief Magistrate in his or her capacity as a Magistrate of the Local Court,
nothing in this Act or any other law requires the Chief Magistrate to devote the whole of his or her time to the duties of a Judge.

Section 14(5) of the Local Court Act 2007 enables a Chief Magistrate who has been appointed as a Judge to exercise the jurisdiction of the District Court while holding office as the Chief Magistrate by arrangement with the Chief Judge.
[subs (3) insrt Act 63 of 2010 Sch 1.9[2], effective 28 June 2010 ; am Act 60 of 2012 Sch 6, effective 10 September 2012]
The Governor may, by the commission of a person's appointment as a Judge or by a subsequent commission under the public seal of the State, appoint a Judge to be Chief Judge.
Subject to subsection (6) , the Chief Judge shall hold office as Chief Judge so long as he or she holds office as a Judge.
[subs (5) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
With the approval of the Governor, the Chief Judge may resign his or her office as Chief Judge without resigning his or her office as a Judge.
[subs (6) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
A Judge shall, while he or she holds office as such, be deemed to have been appointed a justice of the peace.
[subs (7) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

A person who vacates office as a Judge may, despite vacating his or her office, complete or otherwise continue to deal with any matters relating to proceedings that have been heard, or partly heard, by the person before vacating his or her office (including proceedings that were instituted before the commencement of this subsection).
[subs (8) insrt Act 64 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]

While a person completes or otherwise continues under subsection (8) to deal with any matters relating to proceedings that have been heard or partly heard by the person before vacating office, the person has all the entitlements and functions of a Judge and, for the purpose of those proceedings, is taken to continue to be a Judge.
[subs (9) insrt Act 64 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 13.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 3(1), s 44.
A District Court judge is a “judicial officer” ( s 3(1) of the Judicial Officers Act 1986) and retires at age 72: s 44 of the Judicial Officers Act 1986.

The basic principles governing the exercise of the power of appointment of judges are examined in: Attorney-General (NSW) v Quin (1990) 170 CLR 1; 93 ALR 1 ; cf Macrae v A-G (NSW) (1987) 9 NSWLR 268. The manner of the use of the public seal of the state and specifically whether it was necessary for the governor personally to attend to its affixation (relevantly concerning the appointment of a District Court judge) is discussed in R v Lars (aka Larsson) (1994) 33 NSWLR 301; BC9405319 (CCA) (rejected submission that there is a constitutional obligation upon the governor to personally affix or use the public seal of the state, which was not capable of being delegated).
[s 14 rep Act 236 of 1987 s 2 and Sch 1]
The Judges (other than the Chief Judge) are entitled to be paid remuneration in accordance with the Statutory and Other Offices Remuneration Act, 1975 .
[subs (1) am Act 21 of 1995 s 3 and Sch 2]
The remuneration referred to in subsection (1) and payable to a Judge shall be paid to the Judge so long as he or she continues to hold office.
[subs (2) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
However, a Judge is not entitled to the remuneration referred to in subsection (1) for any period for which the Judge is on leave without pay (being leave that is agreed to by the Judge).
[subs (3) insrt Act 56 of 2009 Sch 1.11, effective 17 July 2009]
[s 15 subst Act 4 of 1976 s 28 and Sch 5]
The Chief Judge is entitled to a like style and title as that to which a Judge of the Supreme Court (other than the Chief Justice and the President of the Court of Appeal) is entitled.
The Chief Judge is entitled to the same remuneration as that to which a Judge of the Supreme Court (other than the Chief Justice and the President of the Court of Appeal) is entitled.
[s 15A insrt Act 21 of 1995 s 3]

leg:level-vrnt.toc-caption: [DCA s 16] s 16 Vacancy in office of or absence of Chief Judge

leg:heading.title: Vacancy in office of or absence of Chief Judge

p.text: Where there is a vacancy in the office of Chief Judge, or the Chief Judge is absent from duty, the senior of the other Judges willing to act as Chief Judge shall, if there is no Acting Chief Judge appointed under section 17 , act as Chief Judge, and shall, while so acting, have the powers and authorities and fulfil the duties of the Chief Judge.
[subs (1) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]
For the purposes only in subsection (1) —

the Judges shall have seniority between themselves according to the dates of their commissions as Judges under this Act or the District Courts Act, 1912 , a Judge whose commission is dated earlier than that of another Judge being senior to that other Judge; and

if the commissions of two or more Judges bear the same date, those Judges shall have seniority between themselves according to the seniority assigned to them by their commissions or, failing any such assignment, according to the order of their being sworn.
The Governor may, by commission under the public seal of the State, appoint a Judge to be Acting Chief Judge during such period as the Chief Judge may be absent from duty.
[subs (1) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3]

While holding office, the Acting Chief Judge shall have the powers and authorities and fulfil the duties of the Chief Judge, and is entitled to be paid remuneration at the rate provided for the Chief Judge.
[subs (2) am Act 4 of 1976 s 28 and Sch 5]
The Governor may, by commission under the public seal of the State, appoint any qualified person to act as a Judge from a time not exceeding 12 months to be specified in the commission.
[subs (1) am Act 236 of 1987 s 2 and Sch 1]
In subsection (1) , qualified person means a person qualified for appointment as a Judge.

The person so appointed, for the time and subject to the conditions or limitations specified in the person's commission, shall have the powers and authorities and fulfil the duties of a Judge and shall, for the purposes of this or any other Act other than the Statutory and Other Offices Remuneration Act 1975 , be deemed to be a Judge.
[subs (3) am Act 32 of 1994 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

The person so appointed may, despite the expiration of the period of the person's appointment, complete or otherwise continue to deal with any matters relating to proceedings that have been heard, or partly heard, by the person before the expiration of that period.
[subs (3A) insrt Act 108 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1]

While a person completes or otherwise continues under subsection (3A) to deal with any matters relating to proceedings that have been heard or partly heard by the person before the expiration of the person’s appointment, the person has all the entitlements and functions of a Judge (subject to the conditions and limitations specified in the person’s commission) and, for the purposes of those proceedings, is taken to continue to be a Judge.
[subs (3AA) insrt Act 64 of 2005 s 3 and Sch 1, effective 1 July 2005]

The person so appointed is entitled to be paid remuneration in accordance with the Statutory and Other Offices Remuneration Act 1975 . The remuneration payable to such a person is to be paid to the person so long as he or she continues to hold office.
[subs (3B) insrt Act 30 of 1996 s 3 and Sch 1]

A retired Judge of the Court or of another court in New South Wales (including a retired judicial member of the Industrial Commission or the Industrial Relations Commission) may be so appointed even though the retired Judge has reached the age of 72 years (or will have reached that age before the appointment expires), but may not be so appointed for any period that extends beyond the day on which he or she reaches the age of 75 years.
[subs (4) subst Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 4 ; am Act 169 of 1989 s 3 and Sch 3 ; Act 56 of 1990 s 3 and Sch 1 ; Act 121 of 1996 s 1 and Sch 4]

A person who is or has been a judge of the Federal Court of Australia or of the Supreme Court, District Court or County Court of another State or Territory may be so appointed even though that person has reached the age of 72 years (or will have reached that age before the appointment expires), but may not be so appointed for any period that extends beyond the day on which he or she reaches the age of 75 years.
[subs (4A) insrt Act No 85 of 2001 s 2 and Sch 2]

A person who is or has been an associate Judge of the Supreme Court of New South Wales may be so appointed even though that person has reached the age of 72 years (or will have reached that age before the appointment expires), but may not be so appointed for any period that extends beyond the day on which he or she reaches the age of 75 years.
[subs (4B) insrt Act No 88 of 2010 Sch 3]

The conditions or limitations specified in a commission under this section may exclude the whole or any part of the period of appointment from being regarded as prior judicial service (within the meaning of section 8 of the Judges' Pensions Act 1953) by the person.
[subs (5) subst Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 4 ; am Act 94 of 1991 s 3 and Sch 1]
A person appointed under this section may be appointed under the title of Acting Judge or Associate Judge.
[subs (6) insrt Act 10 of 1988 s 3 and Sch 4]
Legislation cited in [DCA s 18.5] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 18.

Section 18 gives only the governor the authority to appoint acting judges. The governor's office is regulated by Pt 2A (ss 9A–9I) and Pt 4 of the Constitution Act 1902. Section 35A of that Act preserves the constitutional convention that the governor in carrying out her functions acts only on the advice of the Executive Council. There is no power for anyone other than the governor so acting to appoint an acting judge. No judge has power to direct the governor to appoint any person to be a judge: Hagan v ICAC [2002] NSWSC 686; BC200204465 at [10] ; cf Re Governor, Goulburn Correctional Centre; Ex parte Eastman (1999) 200 CLR 322; 165 ALR 171 (applicant alleged that he was not duly convicted on the basis that the presiding acting judge was not validly appointed by the governor-in-council but by the Australian Capital Territory Executive). Arrangements for the transaction of business in the court are dealt with by the Chief Judge and the appointment of a particular judge to hear a particular case is not justiciable: Rajski v Wood (1989) 18 NSWLR 512 at 526 : Hagan v ICAC , above, at [11]. It has been suggested the absence of security of tenure in relation to acting judges may make them reluctant to make findings against persons prominent in the political party forming the executive and to whom he or she may be beholden for reappointment: Hagan v ICAC , above, at [19]–[23]. However, it is doubtful that a judge has the power to make a formal and binding declaration that a particular case is not suitable for an acting judge to hear: Hagan v ICAC [2003] NSWCA 93; BC200302557 at [31]–[32] (application that proceedings be determined by non-Supreme Court justices and by a selected justice who was "beyond political influence and the influence of the Australian Labor Party" — application dismissed by Dunford J and Court of Appeal).

Section 18 is not invalid and the circumstances of the appointment of acting judges (including the primary judge) were not shown to have undermined the institutional integrity of the District Court in 2009–2010: Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 per Basten JA at [103], [125], [127], Allsop P & Macfarlan JA agreeing (submissions based on Forge v Australian Securities and Investments Commission (2006) 228 CLR 45; 229 ALR 223; [2006] HCA 44; BC200606891 , and the failure of the State to produce material demonstrating any “pressing necessity” for the appointment of the primary judge as an acting judge, or the appointments of others made at approximately the same times were insufficient to show invalidity of the appointment). Where allegations of invalidity are raised by a litigant the court should not inquire into the institutional integrity of a particular court beyond the period necessary to dispose of the specific case: Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5), above, at [119].
Legislation cited in [DCA s 18.10] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 18(3A).

DCA s 18(3A) allows an Acting Judge to complete matters after the expiration of the period of appointment. The power includes the continuation of a substantive hearing, delivery of reserved judgment and the determination of interest and costs. It does not include power to determine preliminary interlocutory matters: Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 at [84]–[85] per Basten JA, Allsop P and Macfarlan JA agreeing (power includes determining an an application to call fresh evidence at the hearing of a substantive appeal).
Legislation cited in [DCA s 18.15] below. LawNow subscribers click through for daily updates and historical versions.
(NSW) District Court Act 1973 s 13(2), ss 18(4A).
(NSW) Constitution Act 1902 Pt 9.
(NSW) Judicial Officers Act 1986 s 44.

DCA ss 18(4A) and s 13(2) are not invalid and do not repeal or amend any part of Pt 9 of the Constitution Act 1902. DCA s 18(4A) overcomes the effect of s 44 of the Judicial Officers Act 1986 (NSW) in imposing a retirement age for judicial officers of 72 years: Downey v Acting District Court Judge Boulton (No 5) (2010) 272 ALR 705; [2010] NSWCA 240; BC201006774 per Basten JA at [129]–[132] Allsop P and Macfarlan JA agreeing.
